p: The Allium genus, which belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family, contains approximately 700 species of plants, such as Allium cepa (onion), Allium sativum (garlic), Allium schoenoprasum (chives), and Allium tuberosum (garlic chives). All are important due to their commercial character and nutritional value [ 45]. Allium tuberosum is a perennial plant that grows in many countries in Asia and whose aerial parts are edible green vegetables common to the Chinese. A. tuberosum has an odor similar to the smell of garlic and other Allium plants due to the presence of sulfur-containing compounds [ 46].
